entry.title: Re: ALV Background spool open as Excel file
entry.content:
I think only very few people saw a spool request of type binary (possibly linked to PDF).

Many would say that it's not possible.

Spool means something to be printed. It's not intended to solely store and download files.

Keep it simple, do something that you know is possible.

Store as a file, propose a transaction to download it and give authorizations to users.

entry.title: Re: CAP Calling a Function Module (RFC) in Node.js using...
entry.content:
When you add the service function (using Basic Auth), the following line is automatically added to your .npmrc file (and the file is created if it doesn‚Äôt already exist):
@SAP-rfc:registry=https://73554900100900009091.npmsrv.repositories.cloud.sap
//73554900100900009091.npmsrv.repositories.cloud.sap/...

However, you need to manually update the .npmrc file to include the Base64 authentication token.
After editing, your file should look like this:
@SAP-rfc:registry=https://73554900100900009091.npmsrv.repositories.cloud.sap
//73554900100900009091.npmsrv.cdn.repositories.cloud.sap/:_auth="<base64>"
//73554900100900009091.npmsrv.repositories.cloud.sap/:_auth=<basicAuthAdded>

Once you‚Äôve added the authentication information, try running the installation again I think it should work.

entry.title: Making Every Tool a Source of Insight: SAP Signavio Transformation Manager APIs Now in Beta
entry.content:
Announcing the Beta Release of SAP Signavio Transformation Manager APIs 

We are excited to announce that two new SAP Signavio Transformation Manager APIs ‚Äî Initiatives API and Insights API ‚Äî are now available in Beta on the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. 

These APIs open SAP Signavio Transformation Manager to your enterprise landscape, allowing you to connect, automate, and accelerate continuous improvement across all your business transformation programs. 

Why This Matters 

SAP Signavio Transformation Manager is the central cockpit for defining, tracking, and realizing transformation initiatives. With the new APIs, it becomes a living, connected system that turns every tool you already use into part of your transformation story. 

  • Make every tool in your landscape a source of insights and a value driver 
    Whether it‚Äôs SAP Cloud ALM, Jira, Power BI, or a custom analytics dashboard, you can now bring operational data and performance metrics directly into your transformation overview. 
  • Create a single source of truth for improvement programs and for insights 
    Eliminate silos between business and IT. All initiatives, KPIs, and improvement opportunities can now be centralized within SAP Signavio Transformation Manager for consistent reporting and governance. 
  • Unlock infinite context with incredibly low effort 
    Automatically link insights from across your systems to the right initiatives. No manual data mapping, no repeated updates ‚Äî the APIs make context creation and synchronization effortless. 

The result: faster alignment, clearer accountability, and measurable value realization across your entire transformation portfolio. 

What‚Äôs Included in Beta 

Initiatives API 

  • Manage the full lifecycle of initiatives (create, read, update, delete). 
  • Search and filter by attributes such as status, owner, or value driver. 
  • Maintain governance through standardized authorization endpoints. 

Insights API 

  • Perform full CRUD operations on insights. 
  • Link insights back to initiatives for traceability and transparency. 

Who Should Try It 

  • Customers embedding SAP Signavio Transformation Manager data into enterprise reporting or improvement workflows. 
  • Transformation leaders looking to unify program tracking across multiple systems. 
  • Developers exploring automation and AI-driven value realization scenarios. 

Getting Started 

  1. Visit the SAP Business Accelerator Hub.
  2. Review the API documentation on the SAP Help Portal for implementation examples. 
  3. Share your feedback with the SAP Signavio product team via signavio_ecosystem@sap.com ‚Äî your input during the Beta phase will shape the General Availability release. 

What‚Äôs Next 

Following the Beta cycle, the APIs will reach General Availability with additional capabilities for value cases, extended integrations, and Objectives API support. 

Call to Action 

Start connecting your systems, automate the flow of insights, and build a unified view of transformation in action. 
Be part of the next chapter of SAP Signavio Transformation Manager.

entry.title: Master and Transactions data details required when importing data from SFM to Green Ledger
entry.content:
1. When moving Material Movements from S4 and Emissions from SFM (Valuation), data is imported into SFM from S/4HANA. Requirement to confirm if there is a need to import transaction data from S/4HANA to SFM as well, as only emission factor is needed to be sent to Green Ledger.
  2. When import from SFM, what are all the master data and transactional data flows from SFM to S/4HANA for Material movement? 




------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Master and Transactions data details required when im...
entry.content:
Response to Question 1:
Yes, transaction data is transferred from S/4HANA into SFM, and this data is essential for footprint calculation.
While it is theoretically possible to calculate footprints without importing transactional data (by using manual activities), this approach is typically limited to corporate-level footprinting.
Given that your question refers to S/4HANA integration, it‚Äôs likely that you are referring to product-level footprints, where transactional and goods movement data play a critical role.

Response to Question 2:
Assuming you are referring to outbound integration with the Green Ledger, SFM can publish or send footprint data, but not master or transactional data.
The ‚Äúimport from SFM‚Äù scenario in Green Ledger only involves importing the calculated carbon footprints from SFM into Green Ledger‚Äîno master or transactional data is transferred.

Green Ledger provides three specific options for importing data from SFM:

  • Material Movements

  • Energy Flows

  • Other Carbon Flows

For detailed information on what is included in each of these categories, the Green Ledger team would be the best point of contact.

entry.title: How to handle different fiscal year variants and fixed asset depreciation when setting up two codes
entry.content:
Hi Dear Experts,

Subject: How to handle different fiscal year variants and fixed asset depreciation when setting up two company codes

Content:
We currently have two company codes that follow different accounting principles and fiscal year variants.
For example:

  • Company A follows Japanese GAAP, with a fiscal year from April to March.

  • Company B follows Chinese GAAP, with a fiscal year from January to December.

In this case, since the fiscal years are different, I believe we need to set up two separate company codes (company codes = ledgers).
However, I‚Äôm facing some issues and would like advice on the following points:

‚ë† Cost Accounting:
Because the fiscal years differ, should the cost accounting also follow the fiscal year variant?
Does that mean I should set up two controlling areas, each corresponding to one company code (i.e., one company code ‚Üî one controlling area)?

‚ë° Fixed Assets:
Suppose Company B adjusts the useful life of an asset or adds additional value in January.
Then Company B will need to recalculate depreciation starting from January.
However, for Company A, January still belongs to the previous fiscal year (not yet closed), so this recalculation may affect the prior year and cause inconsistent depreciation amounts between the two companies.

In this case, should I still create two company codes (or ledgers)?
And how should I configure the depreciation areas or related settings for fixed assets to avoid inconsistencies due to different fiscal year variants?

I can‚Äôt think of a clean solution for this situation, so I‚Äôd really appreciate any suggestions or best practices from others who have handled similar cases.

Please suggest.

Thank you very much.Best Regards!

SAP S/4HANA SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA SAP S/4HANA Finance for group reporting SAP S/4HANA Finance

entry.title: Why clean data is the foundation of enterprise success
entry.content:
Why clean data is the foundation of enterprise success

We‚Äôve all been there: reports that don‚Äôt align, systems that refuse to speak the same language, and data that seems to have a mind of its own. It‚Äôs frustrating, time-consuming, and costly. Unclean data doesn‚Äôt just cause confusion - it multiplies complexity. It clogs business processes, drives up the number of upgrade cycles, and makes every transformation effort harder than it needs to be. And these aren‚Äôt just data quality issues - they‚Äôre symptoms of a fragmented data foundation that slows progress and limits innovation.

Now imagine a world where every decision is powered by data that just works: accurate, consistent, governed, and seamlessly connected across the enterprise. That‚Äôs what clean data makes possible. It‚Äôs the quiet engine behind transformation -the unseen force that fuels trust, agility, and innovation.

Clean data turns chaos into clarity. It enables governed, reusable data products built on shared semantics and harmonized master and reference data - so information flows freely across domains, analytics deliver truth instead of noise, and AI scales with confidence. Building on this foundation, the clean core approach takes the next step - transforming data clarity into business agility. It helps organizations unlock the full power of intelligent, connected operations by relying on harmonized, semantically linked data. When processes are standardized around proven best practices and strategic extensions are enabled for differentiation, businesses gain the agility to evolve without complexity.

With SAP Business Suite at the center, this approach keeps systems current, fuels continuous innovation, and paves the way for faster adoption of AI - turning trusted data into a true engine of transformation.

The business power of clean data

Clean data is more than a technical concern - it‚Äôs a true business enabler. By embedding clean data practices into the core of your enterprise, you can unlock:

  • Trustworthy decision-making ‚Äì ensure leaders can rely on accurate, consistent information at every level of the business.
  • Regulatory confidence ‚Äì meet compliance requirements seamlessly with transparent, auditable data.
  • AI and automation readiness ‚Äì create the reliable foundation required to scale advanced analytics, automation, and intelligent technologies.
  • Operational excellence ‚Äì reduce inefficiencies caused by data errors, rework, and duplication, freeing teams to focus on higher-value outcomes.

 

Clean core data whitepaper

That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm excited to introduce our new Clean core data whitepaper, designed for organizations moving from ERP to SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. This paper explores how to make this vision a reality. Inside, you‚Äôll find practical guidance on implementing clean data practices, sustaining them at scale, and unlocking the full potential of your enterprise data.

A sneak preview of what‚Äôs inside

Here‚Äôs what you‚Äôll find inside:

  • The five pillars of clean core data  - explore the essential dimensions of clean data: strategy, governance, quality, volume efficiency, and protection - each designed to strengthen your enterprise data foundation.
  • A practical measurement framework -  learn how to assess data maturity and governance using KPIs aligned with the RISE with SAP Methodology and dashboard.
  • Operationalizing the data product economy - discover how to leverage SAP Business Data Cloud and SAP Master Data Governance to deliver governed, reusable, and high-value data products.
  • Harmonizing SAP and non-SAP data - See how a unified semantic layer ensures interoperability and consistency, while keeping custom extensions decoupled on SAP BTP.
  • Driving seamless upgrades and intelligent insights - gain guidance on reducing infrastructure complexity, minimizing technical debt, and fueling trustworthy AI and analytics with a clean, future-ready data core.

Each chapter of the whitepaper takes you deeper into the journey:

  1. Building a clean core: Overcoming data chaos for a modern, compliant enterprise
  2. Chart the path to your clean data vision: Leverage clean core data to achieve business success
  3. Data framework: Dive deep into the building blocks of clean core data
  4. The cornerstones of a clean core data architecture

 Driving data confidence with the RISE with SAP Methodology

Every successful digital transformation starts with one question: how do we turn data into continuous business value? Within the clean data framework, the answer begins with the RISE with SAP Methodology. It provides a clear roadmap, guiding organizations from identifying data challenges to building, monitoring, and scaling a sustainable clean data strategy. Through automated clean data KPIs, organizations can track the state of their data in real time - across both projects and day-to-day operations. All of this comes together in the RISE with SAP Methodology Dashboard, offering a unified view of data health, performance, and progress toward true data-driven agility.

Ready to take the first step?

Clean data is not a one-time project - it‚Äôs a journey and a discipline. The first step is to explore the Whitepaper on clean data and see how organizations can establish a foundation for smarter decisions, efficient operations, and long-term resilience.

üëâ Download the Clean core data whitepaper

entry.title: CDS : How to define default Key Display in Analytical queries
entry.content:
This blog explains how to define default key display settings in analytical queries, ensuring user-friendly key visualization. Many Hierarchy Nodes and Dimensions have compounded keys that are shown as a long-concatenated keys during runtime. Sometimes its not needed to see the concatenated long key. To enhance readability, @AnalyticsDetails.query.keyDisplay annotation is use to specify the default display behaviour for key.

Annotation: @AnalyticsDetails.query.keyDisplay

Accepted Values:

  • #NOT_COMPOUND: Displays the key as a non-compounded characteristic value.
  • #COMPOUND: Displays the key as a compounded characteristic value (concatenated long key).
  • #CONTEXT_DEPENDENT: Displays the key based on its uniqueness. If the compounded key is unique due to drill-down selection, it will be shown as non-compounded

Example

@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_ALLOWED
@EndUserText.label: 'Query: Simple Example for Key display'
define transient view entity ZLR_PC_KEY_DISP 
provider contract analytical_query
as projection on ZOQ_FLIGHT {

  
  @AnalyticsDetails.query.axis: #ROWS
  carrid,
  
  @AnalyticsDetails.query: {
      axis: #ROWS,
    totals: #SHOW
  }
  @EndUserText.label: 'ConnectionID Not Compound'
  @AnalyticsDetails.query.keyDisplay: #NOT_COMPOUND
  connid,
  
  @AnalyticsDetails.query.axis: #FREE
  @analytics.hidden: true
  currency,
   
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode: 'currency'
  @EndUserText.label: 'Booking total 2019'
  paymentsum

 
}
where flyear =  '2019'
  and currency = 'EUR'

Output

Release Info

This feature is available from Cloud release 2508

SAP Note: 3600690 - CDS: query display key settings

entry.content:
Hi Zack,

Thanks for your feedback, I really appreciate it.

I tried with the solution you suggested and created the onChange rule which I then assigned to date of birth field. However the rule does not seem to trigger at all, I ran the rule trace and there is no sign of the transaction. I selected Rules for Hire/Rehire Processes scenario and created the below logic.

But that actually gave me the though to try something else. I created another rule, but this time with a different scenario, Trigger onChange Rules for HRIS Elements. In this scenario you cannot raise messages, but you can set values for fields, which is what I tried to do. I configured the below rule which will blank the DOB when the DOB of father or mother is less than DOB of a new joiner. It works, but the problem is that it sets the DOB to null when the DOB is less and when it is more than DOB of a new joiner. In the rule trace I can see that when DOB is set to 4th November 2025 and the date in 1979, while DOB of a new joiner is 1987, it still reads it DOB of a dependent as on or before the new joiner's DOB and executes the action. I tried to change the logic to on or after, it does the same. I changed it to after and then to before (without "on"), in that case the rule does not trigger.

I don't understand why the system reads these operators in that way, to me this is a bug.

entry.title: SAP Self-Billing Cockpit Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
This guide describes how to set up the integration between the SAP Self-Billing Cockpit and an SAP S/4HANA Cloud system without requiring a cloud connector. It covers both self-billing with automatic posting (SBWAP) and self-billing with invoice creation (SBINV).

Prerequisites

  • You have set up your global account and subaccount.
  • You are assigned the Administrator role for the global account.
  • You are assigned the Security Administrator role for the subaccount to configure authorizations using role collections.

Enabling Communication in SAP S/4HANA Cloud

Creating a Communication User

  1. Log on to the SAP Fiori Launchpad in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.
  2. Open the Maintain Communication Users app: Communication Management > Maintain Communication Users.

     

  3. Choose New.
  4. Enter the name, description, and password for the new user.

     

  5. Choose Create.
  6. Record the user name and password for future use. These are required when you create communication arrangements and destinations to SAP S/4HANA Cloud via the SAP BTP cockpit.

Creating a Communication System

  1. Log on to the SAP Fiori Launchpad in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.
  2. Launch the Communication Systems app: Communication Management > Communication Systems.

     

  3. Choose New to create a communication system.
  4. On the New Communication System screen, specify the system ID and system name.
  5. Choose Create.
  6. In the Technical Data area, specify:
    • The hostname (the host URL of the self-billing tenant excluding https://, e.g. <subdomain>.eu10.selfbilling.cloud.sap)
    • The logical system name
    • The business system name (your subaccount ID assigned by the SAP BTP cockpit)
    The subdomain is defined when you create a subaccount. Ensure it is identifiable and meaningful for you. You can find your subdomain and subaccount ID in the SAP BTP cockpit.

     

  7. In the Users for Inbound Communication area, add a user:
    • On the New Inbound Communication User screen, enter the communication user name you created earlier, specify the authentication method, and save the settings.
  8. In the Users for Outbound Communication area, add a user:
    • On the New Outbound Communication User screen, enter the technical user name you created earlier.
  9. Save your settings and record the communication system name for future use.

Creating Communication Arrangements

Create communication arrangements for the following scenarios before you proceed.

  • SAP_COM_0367
  • SAP_COM_0008
  • SAP_COM_0106
  • SAP_COM_0120
  • SAP_COM_0087
  • SAP_COM_0158
  • SAP_COM_0159
  • SAP_COM_0360

All these scenarios follow the same configuration procedure; this section uses scenario SAP_COM_0367 as an example.

 

  1. Log on to the SAP Fiori Launchpad in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.
  2. Launch the Communication Arrangements app: Communication Management > Communication Arrangements.

     

  3. Choose New.
  4. In New Communication Arrangement, choose SAP_COM_0367 under Scenario, optionally modify the arrangement name, and choose Create.

  5. In the Common Data section, select the communication system you created earlier in Creating a Communication System. The previously created communication user is automatically added to both Inbound and Outbound sections (if applicable).

     

     

  6. If there are any other outbound services, deactivate them and save your settings.

Subscribing to SAP Self-Billing Cockpit

Configuring Destinations

  1. Log on to the SAP BTP cockpit (Cloud Foundry environment) with your registered subaccount.

     

  2. Navigate to Connectivity > Destinations > New Destination to create a new destination for mobile services.

     

  3. In the Destination Configuration wizard, enter:
    • Name: SELFB_DEST_S4HANA
    • URL: Hostname of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system
    • Authentication: Basic Authentication
    • User: The communication user created in ‚ÄúCreating a Communication User‚Äù
    • Password: The password of the communication user created earlier
  4. Save your settings and choose Check Connection to verify the connection.

     

Navigate to Service Marketplace in the navigation tree, locate the SAP Self-Billing Cockpit tile, and open it. Choose Create.

 

In the displayed screen, choose an application plan (e.g., default) and proceed as instructed. After the subscription is complete, the status changes to Subscribed.

 

Assigning Role Collections to Users

You can manage role collections as needed. The following table lists the recommended role collections.

Role Collection Role User Remarks

AdminSAP_BR_ADMINISTRATORA technical user on BTPThis role grants the technical user rights to replicate units of measurement and plants data, to check the integration configuration, and to export data.
Billing_ClerkSAP_SELFB_CLERKBilling clerkThis role allows the billing clerk to log in to self-billing apps, make configurations, check document status, and perform processing tasks.
ArchivingSAP_SELFB_ARCHIVINGUser to process archivingThis role allows the user to log in to self-billing apps and perform archiving.
ConfirmationSAP_SELFB_CR_APIA technical user on BTPThis role allows the technical user to receive confirmation messages from SAP S/4HANA Cloud.
TransmissionSAP_SELFB_TR_APIA technical user on BTPThis role allows the technical user to send transmissions to SAP Self-Billing Cockpit.

Create a technical user in your own IDP service.

  1. Log on to the SAP BTP cockpit (Cloud Foundry environment) with your registered subaccount.
  2. Navigate to Security > Role Collections.
  3. Create a role collection, enter a name and a description, and save the settings.
  4. Select the newly created role collection and edit it by adding the corresponding role.
  5. If you want to verify the setup via API, you can assign the Admin role to the technical user and remember its username and password for later use.

     

Creating Other Communication Arrangements

For Scenario SAP_COM_0564

  1. Log on to the SAP Fiori Launchpad in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.
  2. Open the Communication Arrangements app: Communication Management > Communication Arrangements.

     

  3. Choose New.
  4. In New Communication Arrangement, choose SAP_COM_0564 under Scenario, optionally modify the arrangement name, and choose Create.

     

  5. In the Common Data section, select the communication system created earlier in Creating a Communication System. The previously created communication user is automatically added to both Inbound and Outbound sections.
  6. In the Outbound Services section, enter the path for the following services:

Service Path Remark

Credit/Debit Memo ‚Äì Send Confirmation of Creation with Invoice Reference/api-password/selfbilling-confirmation-service/v1/api/CreditDebitMemoConfirmation_In/V2 
Billing Document ‚Äì Send Confirmation of Fields Updated for Self-Billing/api-password/selfbilling-confirmation-service/v1/api/BillingDocumentUpdateConfirmation_InOnly for SBWAP
Billing Document - Send Confirmation of Simulated Pricing/api-password/selfbilling-confirmation-service/v1/api/BdSimulatePricingConfirmation_In 
Self-Billing Invoice - Send Creation Confirmation/api-password/selfbilling-confirmation-service/v1/api/SelfBillingInvoiceCreationConfirmation_InOnly for SBINV

Note: If you use a custom identity service as an alternative to the SAP ID service, append ?login_hint=%7B%22origin%22%3A%22sap.custom%22%7D to the end of the service path.

The service URL is automatically generated based on the tenant host name and the entered path. For example: <Self-Billing Tenant URL>/api-password/selfbilling-confirmation-service/v1/api/CreditDebitMemoConfirmation_In and <Self-Billing Tenant URL>/api-password/selfbilling-confirmation-service/v1/api/BillingDocumentUpdateConfirmation_In.

 

If there are other outbound services you do not use, deactivate them and save your settings. For example, if you only use SBWAP and no pricing simulation, you can deactivate them as shown below.

 

For Scenario SAP_COM_0002 (SBWAP only)

  1. Log on to the SAP Fiori Launchpad in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.
  2. Open the Communication Arrangements app: Communication Management > Communication Arrangements.

     

  3. Choose New.
  4. In New Communication Arrangement, choose SAP_COM_0002 under Scenario, optionally modify the arrangement name, and choose Create.

  5. In the Common Data section, select the communication system created earlier in Creating a Communication System. The communication user is automatically added to Inbound and Outbound sections.
  6. In the Outbound Services section, enter the path for the ‚ÄúJournal Entry ‚Äì Change (Asynchronous) Confirmation‚Äù service: /api-password/selfbilling-confirmation-service/v1/api/JournalEntryBulkChangeConfirmation_In
    Note: If you use a custom identity service, append the login hint as described above.
  7. If there are other outbound services, deactivate them and save your settings.

For Scenario SAP_COM_0114

  1. Log on to the SAP Fiori Launchpad in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.
  2. Open Communication Arrangements (Communication Management > Communication Arrangements).
  3. Choose New.
  4. Select SAP_COM_0114 under Scenario, optionally modify the arrangement name, and choose Create.
  5. In Common Data, select the communication system created earlier. The communication user is automatically added to Inbound and Outbound sections.
  6. In the Outbound Services section, set the path for the Unit of Measurement ‚Äì Replicate (A2X) service to: /api-password/selfbilling-core-service/v1/erpintegration/data/UnitOfMeasurementMasterDataReplicationBundleRequest_In
    Note: If you use a custom identity service, append the login hint as described above.
  7. Deactivate all other outbound services.
  8. Under Additional Properties, define Replication Model and save its value (e.g., SB_UOM) for future use.
  9. Navigate to the SAP Fiori Launchpad and launch Replicate by Replication Model. From the dropdown, choose an option beginning with the replication model defined in Step 8 (e.g., SB_UOM_999), then choose Replicate.

For Scenario SAP_COM_0116

  1. Log on to the SAP Fiori Launchpad in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system.
  2. Open Communication Arrangements (Communication Management > Communication Arrangements).
  3. Choose New.
  4. Select SAP_COM_0116 under Scenario, optionally modify the arrangement name, and choose Create.
  5. In Common Data, select the communication system created earlier. The communication user is automatically added to Inbound and Outbound sections.
  6. In the Outbound Services section, set the path for the Plants ‚Äì Replicate service to: /api-password/selfbilling-core-service/v1/erpintegration/data/plantsSync
    Note: If you use a custom identity service, append the login hint as described above.
  7. Deactivate all other outbound services.
  8. Under Job Execution Details, define the fields to suit your needs (daily execution is recommended).
  9. Under Additional Properties, define Replication Model and save its value (e.g., SB_PLANT) for future use.
  10. Navigate to the SAP Fiori Launchpad and launch Replicate by Replication Model. From the dropdown, choose an option beginning with the replication model defined in Step 9 (e.g., SB_PLANT_999), then choose Replicate.

Verifying the Setup

After completing all steps, your billing clerk can access SAP Self-Billing Cockpit:

  1. Log on to the SAP BTP cockpit (Cloud Foundry environment) with your registered subaccount.
  2. Navigate to your application plan, then choose Go to Application.
  3. You can now view the apps in SAP Self-Billing Cockpit.

     

You can also verify via API:

  1. In Postman, create a GET request to: https://<subdomain>/api-password/selfbilling-customizing-service/v1/api/check.
  2. Under Authorization, select Basic Auth and enter the username and password of the technical user with the role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR.
  3. If all checks in odataCheck are 200 OK and there are no items in Configuration Missing in additionalCheck, the setup is correct.

     

Summary

To set up integration between SAP Self-Billing Cockpit and an SAP S/4HANA Cloud system, we first need to enable communication in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system and then subscribe to an application plan of SAP Self-Billing Cockpit via the SAP BTP cockpit.

If you‚Äôre interested in similar topics, you can follow its tag and my profile.

Surely, you‚Äôre cordially invited to provide your feedback and insights in the comments section.

Additional Information

 

  • SAP Self-Billing Cockpit Product Documentation
  • SAP Self-Billing Cockpit on SAP Store

  • [Feature]Side-by-side extensiblity to custom the product and customer material mapping logic(ABAP)
  • [Feature] Self-Billing Ability to integrate with SAP Analytics Cloud

entry.title: Re: Forcing a Refresh of M_TABLE_PERSISTENCE_STATISTICS S...
entry.content:
Good morning,

I‚Äôm revisiting this question as it seems there has been no response so far.
It‚Äôs a pity ‚Äî the SAP Community has unfortunately lost some of its engagement with recent platform upgrades.

For anyone who might encounter the same issue, and since SAP‚Äôs documentation on this topic is not very detailed, here are the key points and steps that may help:

üîπJob Responsible for Refreshing the Statistics

The job that updates these statistics is View Global_Table_Persistence_Statistics with ID 5010.

To check when these statistics were last updated, connect to the HANA tenant corresponding to your ABAP instance, and run the following commands:

su - sidadm
hdbsql -i 00 -d SID localhost:30013 -u system
SQL> SELECT ID, STATUS, INTERVALLENGTH, RETENTION_DAYS_DEFAULT, LATEST_START_SNAPSHOT_ID FROM _SYS_STATISTICS.STATISTICS_SCHEDULE WHERE ID = 5010;

Example output:
5010, "Idle", 60, 365, "2025-11-05 06:42:50.000000000"

üîπTriggering the Job Manually

SAP does not provide a built-in tool to trigger this job manually (‚ÄúStart Now‚Äù).
The simplest approach is to temporarily reduce the job interval so that it runs sooner.

Below is an example procedure:

  1. Check the ABAP spool (SP01) disk size
    SELECT (disk_size) FROM m_table_persistence_statistics WHERE table_name='TST03';
    Example result: 5129850464

  2. Check when the job last ran
    SELECT ID, STATUS, INTERVALLENGTH, RETENTION_DAYS_DEFAULT, LATEST_START_SNAPSHOT_ID FROM _SYS_STATISTICS.STATISTICS_SCHEDULE WHERE ID = 5010;

  3. Temporarily set the interval to 1 minute
    UPDATE _sys_statistics.statistics_schedule SET intervallength=60 WHERE ID=5010;

  4. Verify the job execution
    SELECT ID, STATUS, INTERVALLENGTH, RETENTION_DAYS_DEFAULT, LATEST_START_SNAPSHOT_ID FROM _SYS_STATISTICS.STATISTICS_SCHEDULE WHERE ID = 5010;

  5. Restore the default interval
    UPDATE _sys_statistics.statistics_schedule SET intervallength=21600 WHERE ID=5010;

  6. Confirm that the statistics have been refreshed
    SELECT (disk_size) FROM m_table_persistence_statistics WHERE table_name='TST03';
    Example updated value: 5107056784

I hope this helps others facing the same question.
Have a great day

entry.title: Enhanced Permission Roles for Accessing Employee Data During Rehire 2H 2025
entry.content:
Why should you use this new feature?

This enhancement will enable you to define target populations for rehiring on old employment and rehiring on new employment to ensure compliance with employee data privacy by restricting unauthorized users from being able to access and process personal and employment information of employees outside of their permitted scope.

This enhancement only applies when rehiring using the Duplicate Check through Add New Employee. This is in line with Product Management‚Äôs long-term strategy to have one place for users to process rehires and to eventually deprecate the Rehire Inactive Employee tool.  Please refer to my earlier blog post for more information on the deprecation plans: Deprecation of Rehire Inactive Employee - 2H 2025 ... - SAP Community

This blog post contains the steps for configuring the feature and the resulting system behavior. We have provided the flexibility to define target populations when rehiring on old employment or rehiring on new employment, or both.  We wanted to provide the flexibility in case your processes differ for both scenarios.

How do you enable the feature?

Step 1 ‚Äì Activate the feature in Manage Data

Go to Manage Data ‚Äì Hire/Rehire Configuration and edit the object MATCHINGUSERCONFIG.

Enable the target population for rehire on old employment and/or rehire on new employment by changing the value to ‚ÄúYes‚Äù

For more information about how to configure this object please refer to the help documentation: Creating the Hire/Rehire Configuration Object (Including Duplicate Check) | SAP Help Portal

Result:

The rehire permissions are updated to include permissions where a target needs to be defined.  

Rehire permissions before activation of the feature:

Rehire permissions after activation of the feature:

Step 2 ‚Äì Update Permissions

You will need to select these new permissions in all the roles where the rehire permissions have been granted.

The target populations which have been assigned to the roles with the above permissions will be respected.  If you need to define a target population you can use Manage Permission Groups to do this. To find out more about implementing role based permissions please refer to the help documentation  Role-Based Permissions | SAP Help Portal

Where can I see the resulting change in system behaviour?

Go to Add New Employee and enter Identity, Name Information, Biographical Information and National ID Information.  When you click Continue, the system will check the database for matches (matching is dependent on how you have configured the Hire/Rehire Configuration in Manage Data) This initial check does not respect the RBP, the system will return all matches regardless of where and who they are.

The system will display all matches it finds:

(test data shown from a sales demo instance)

In this example, our logged in user is in Germany and is only allowed access to employees in Germany.  They are hiring an employee called Jens Baer. The duplicate check has found two matches, one in Germany and one in the UK.

The system checks the target population of the logged in user when they click on either Accept Match or Rehire with new employment.

If the logged in user tries to rehire the inactive employee in the UK they will receive the following error message:

Whether the Accept Match and Rehire with new employment buttons are displayed will depend on whether you have enforced a new employment on change of legal entity. This is configured the Employment Settings Configuration in Manage Data.  To find out more about enforcing a new employment please refer to the help documentation Creating the Employment Settings Configuration Object | SAP Help Portal

Important Notes

If your instance has Onboarding activated, then you will not be able to use this feature just yet. If you try to activate the feature you will see the following error message:

Our roadmap includes plans to enable customers to use the feature where they have both Employee Central and Onboarding activated.

When you activate this feature the permission to the Rehire Inactive Employee tool disappears and you will no longer have access to this tool. The reason being the Rehire Inactive Employee tool does not respect RBP, the target population check is only respected in the Duplicate Check.

After you have activated the feature you can revert back if needs be.  Please make sure you reinstate the original rehire permissions in all impacted roles.

Feel free to reach out and leave a comment below this blog post if you have any questions or need further clarification on this process. Your feedback is always welcome!

entry.title: Sequentially Retry HTTP Calls (Re-Read ETag and Repost on Error) in SAP Build Process Automation
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I‚Äôm working on an SAP Build Process Automation workflow that requires handling retries for a failed HTTP call in a sequential manner.

Here‚Äôs my current setup:

  • I first read the ETag using an HTTP GET request.

  • Then, I post a Goods Issue using that ETag.

  • Sometimes the Post Goods Issue call fails because the ETag becomes outdated.
    In that case, I need to reread the ETag and retry the Post request with the new ETag.

I‚Äôve tried using a Branch step with ‚ÄúContinue on Error‚Äù enabled, and while it does allow the retry to trigger, it runs the branches in parallel.


This causes both the failed and successful calls to execute simultaneously, which isn‚Äôt ideal.

Is there an alternative way to handle this error scenario sequentially within the workflow?

Manual  work is not feasible for 200 programs with 7000 items. 50+ SCORMS and  500+ content.

entry.title: Old VRP forms lost data after completion phase
entry.content:
Hi experts,

Our client realized during an audit process that their compensation worksheets from a previous campaign (all on completed stage) lost part of the calculated data. The collective amount calculated in the following standard fields became blank totalBusinessPerformancePercent and goalResultsPayoutAmountGrandTotal. üò≥

This is occuring on a production environnement with no 2H2025 yet.

The worksheets were not greyed out, just got a 0 value. This occured for all workheets of the same template. No update actions has been done from our checks.

We found out that there was a change in the way the Bonus Plan BR was displayed (no change tracked on the BR for this): 

BEFORE (once we had all data on the worksheets)

AFTER (once the collective amount = 0)

The error message says "We‚Äôve adjusted the rule to be technically stable for transport and import. Please save the rule to make any potential technical changes permanent. This does not affect your rule configuration."

The issue has been resolved by selecting the value again and save it. A Bonus calculation has been done again after this. Prior that, the modification of the BR was in october 2023.

This issue occured on the 2025 campaign only. All campaigns are using the same rule since 2023. We have no issue on the 2024 campaign.

Even though it was finally resolved with the rule update + bonus calculation, some questions remain for us to fully understand the system's behaviour: 

  • Have you ever encounter a similar situation? 
  • Why was only one template (2025) impacted when all of them (2023 and 2024) were using the same Bonus plan business rule?
  • Once on completed stage, the data in the worksheets are supposed to be "frozen" when the configuration is set as such isn'it?
  • Also, we have difficulties in trying to find out what happened exactly if you do have any tips about how to better investigate on this, that would be very helpfull. 

Thank you very much for any insights

ü§ó

entry.title: Automatic Closure of work orders or internal orders in EAM Specifically

entry.title: Finished Good and Co-/By-Product Valuated at Zero After Production ‚Äì Moving Average Price
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I‚Äôm currently working on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (Manufacturing scenario) and I‚Äôm facing an issue with the inventory valuation after production.

Here is the situation:

  • I have a Finished Good (FG) with a Co-Product and a By-Product (used as a Semi-Finished Good).

  • I generated the BOM which includes the required raw materials.

  • In the Work Center, I assigned:

    • A Cost Center

    • Activity Types (Setup Time, Machine Time, Person Time)

    • Corresponding Rates for each activity type

  • I created a Production Order and during confirmation, the system correctly calculates the total cost (Raw Materials + Setup + Machine + Labor).

  • The cost of the FG and Co-Product is displayed correctly in the production order.

However, after performing the Goods Receipt (GR) for the FG and Co-Product, when I check the Inventory Valuation, I find that both are valuated at zero.
In the Production Order, the costs are correct, but the material valuation in stock is 0.

 

My Question:

How can I configure the system so that it updates the material valuation after production?
Is there any specific step or configuration (for example, settlement or revaluation process) required to make the inventory value reflect the actual production cost?

Note: I‚Äôm using Moving Average Price (V) as the control price for these materials.

Additional Info:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

  • Scenario: Production Order with Co-Products and By-Products

  • BOM and routing correctly maintained

  • Activity rates assigned in the work center

Thanks in advance for your help!
Any insight into configuration or post-processing steps would be appreciated.

entry.title: How do I best speak about Intake & Orchestration?
entry.content:
SAP Ariba Intake Management was released to market on October 24, 2025. In the many customer interactions I have lead since we have started to position our solution, I keep returning to two topics of discussion.

  1. How the casual end user gets lost in a quagmire of fragmented procurement processes and guidance
  2. How unique customer system and process landscapes are

The conversation on the casual end user experience is frequently about the lack of satisfaction end users have with their procurement experience. Anecdotally, we discuss the many systems end users are exposed to, the distinct user experiences they need to become familiar with, and lastly the missing process integration. I use these conversations to lead us into a conversation about our Demand Intake capability, also described as the concept of a single front door. SAP Ariba Intake Management has released a new AI-powered Demand Intake capability specifically targeting the casual end user. The intention of our Demand Intake feature is to provide clear direction and guidance, regardless of the end users procurement intent. In simple terms, our definition of ‚ÄòIntake‚Äô is therefore two fold:

  • Provide the casual end user with the ability to describe their procurement demand in natural language
  • Provide the casual end user with a best fit path to their procurement need. The best fit path is ultimately a system recommendation that will guide the user to the most relevant custom process or to the relevant system.

What are the key value drivers of our Demand Intake capability?

 

Through effective Demand Intake, we minimise the uncertainty of which buying channel is the correct one to follow. But what happens once they are in the right buying channel? When a procurement organisation is well organised, it tends to mean well-defined categories that are underpinned by great systems and processes. For each category, there will be rules and policies that dictate the specific processes to follow. And yet, research shows that 60% of procurement categories remain without real influence from the procurement organisation. That means for many categories, end users might not be given the right guidance, or may not know where to find it. That can lead to a large volume of non-catalog requests. This becomes a burden for the procurement specialists receiving them, but is equally frustrating for the end user due to the lack of process clarity. The end-user wonders how long it will take, which activities need to be completed, and who is involved in the process.

SAP Ariba Intake Management can help. We enable customers to model their unique procurement processes using SAP Build Process Automation. By providing pre-modelled processes that considers policy nuances and industry guidelines, the customer can ensure that their end users are guided through the numerous activities often required before the Buying process is even executed. Approvals, budget checks, sourcing events, supplier management, all of these individual activities can be orchestrated pre-buying, guaranteeing that what is bought has truly been vetted for compliance purposes ultimately minimising maverick spend.

Let there be Light

Now that we have a definition of Intake & Orchestration in the context of the SAP Ariba Intake Management solution, let there be light. One last recurring theme I want to highlight is the lack of visibility given to the end user, also known as ‚Äúthe black hole‚Äù. No wonder when many processes look like this:

Process visibility and status transparency is key to the value of SAP Ariba Intake Management. The end user wants to see the light. To begin with, we aim to answer three simple questions:

  • Where am I in the process?
  • What activities remain?
  • What is the status of the activity?

How do I best speak to my customers about Intake & Orchestration?

Start with the health of their organisation. As stated, research shows that 60% of procurement categories remain without real influence from the procurement organisation. Try to identify one category in which end users are particularly challenged. Engage the customer and work with them to review their procurement processes. Make it an objective to sketch out a process, perhaps in a hands-on workshop. With that foundation you will establish clarity on where end users and the procurement team feel the most pain. The closer you are to the process the easier it is to find a common understanding. It will be that common understanding that allows you to take advantage of the solution value drivers.

entry.title: Reimagining Certification for the Way We Work Today
entry.content:
For decades, certifications exams have followed the same pattern: silent rooms, strict proctors, and no access to the tools you‚Äôd normally use to get work done. The goal was to test what you knew (or could remember) in that moment, not what you could actually do. But work doesn‚Äôt happen that way. And learning certainly doesn‚Äôt either. 

Today, projects are fast paced, connected, and collaborative. When you‚Äôre solving a problem, you don‚Äôt sit in silence ‚Äî you look for information, consult with teammates, and use the tools available to you. With AI now woven into how we all work, it‚Äôs time for certification to evolve too. That‚Äôs why we‚Äôre reimagining SAP Certification. 

From memory to mastery 

SAP Certification is shifting from proctored, multiple-choice tests to performance-based, practical, open-book assessments that mirror real work. 

Instead of answering theoretical questions, you‚Äôll complete realistic challenges that show how you actually apply your SAP knowledge ‚Äî configuring systems, building applications, solving problems, or advising customers on solutions. 

There are two types of practical exams: 

  • System-based: You‚Äôll perform time-boxed tasks directly in SAP systems. 
  • Scenario-based: You‚Äôll interact with an AI avatar to respond to real customer or project situations. (For learners who don‚Äôt want to use AI, we provide an alternative option to upload a video for human review.) 

These ‚Äòopen-book‚Äô exams allow access to resources like SAP Help Portal, SAP Learning site, SAP Community, or SAP Joule for Consultants ‚Äî just as you would use in your daily work. 

Learning that feels real 

This transformation makes certification more meaningful and consistent with how you already learn. The types of practical exercises and scenarios you complete on the SAP Learning site now continue into the exam, so preparation and assessment feel like part of one experience. 

Each exam is time-boxed and focused on proving you can do the work, not just recall facts. There‚Äôs no live proctoring; instead, identity is confirmed through SAP Universal ID, reflecting trust in how professionals really work. You‚Äôll still have to think critically and manage your time, but you‚Äôll do so in a context that mirrors your day-to-day work, not an artificial testing environment. 

A phased rollout for all certifications 

Beginning in November 2025, the first practical certifications, including Solution Architect for SAP Business Technology Platform, SAP Generative AI Developer, SAP Build Developer, SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP BTP System Administrator (new) and RISE with SAP Methodology and Experience (new,) will go live. 

 By 2026, all SAP Certifications will shift to this new, practical format. That means everyone ‚Äì consultants, developers, administrators, or sales professionals ‚Äì will validate their expertise in ways that reflect how work actually gets done.  

Why this matters 

At its core, this transformation is about trust that SAP Certification accurately represents real capability. For learners, it means your credential truly reflects your skills. For employers, it means confidence that a certified professional can perform from day one. 

When we launch at SAP TechEd in Berlin, we‚Äôre not just transforming certification; we‚Äôre redefining what it means to be skilled in the AI era. And for learners everywhere, that means your effort and experience now matter more than ever.  

To learn more about our reimagined certification model, visit SAP Certification and read the FAQ.

entry.title: Re: Issue in Pricing Condition
entry.content:
Routine 333 is designed to copy or derive values from a preceding condition like J1AU or J1AP. It applies exemptions and thresholds based on customer-specific tax settings. The logic is sequential ‚Äî the routine expects the source condition to be calculated first. If the source condition J1AU is not yet evaluated during order entry, the dependent condition J1AX may not display its value until later (e.g., after saving).

In your case, where J1AX doesn‚Äôt show the copied value from J1AU before saving, this logic confirms that:

  • Routine 333 expects J1AU to be calculated first.
  • If J1AU is not finalized during simulation, J1AX won‚Äôt populate.
  • You may need to adjust the pricing procedure sequence or enhance the routine to ensure J1AU is available earlier.

entry.title: How to avoid errors when configuring mandatory event reason for Onboarding?
entry.content:
Overview:

Event Reason is made mandatory for Onboarding at the time of initiation as documented in SAP SuccessFactors What's New Viewer Mandatory Event Reason for Onboarding Process Initiation  and the blog post. Due to this feature, you may start seeing new errors in the Business Process ToDo when onboarding is initiated from Recruiting.

What is the Error observed in the BPE?

Error in Business Process: [{"elementType":null,"key":null,"statusCode":"ERROR","errorInfo":"Event Reason is mandatory for jobInfo"}]

How to avoid the failure of Onboarding Initiation due to event reason validation?

  • Configure a business rule to set the event reason for new hires whose onboarding is initiated from SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting. 
    Reference Link: Configuring Business Rule for Event Reason

(OR)

  • Send the event reason by mapping SAP SuccessFactors Recruiting custom field using the Recruit-to-Hire Data Mapping tool.
    Reference KBA: How to Map Event Reason from RCM to Onboarding

Here are some common errors which could lead to incorrect configuration leading to the error, these troubleshooting steps will allow you to resolve the issue yourself:

  • When using the business rule to configure the event reason, the following pointers should be noted: 

    #1
    In Recruit to Hire Data Mapping, under Job Information, event-reason should not be mapped:

     
    If any mappings exist, please remove the mappings. 

    #2
    The business rule contains the field called "Source System of Onboarding"; however, this field is not readily available in the system. You must create a custom field related to "Source System for Onboarding" in Job Information Data Model.

    If this field is not configured, please configure it.

    #3
    The business rule should be saved as an "onSave" rule in Job Information Data Model with rule context set to "Yes" only for Onboarding. 

    #4
    The Business Rule should be configured as shown in the guide.
    The rule evaluation will fail due to the 2nd condition (In Else If condition) jobInformation.EventReason=Null.
    The correct condition should be jobInformation.EventReason.Value=Null.
    The correct way to configure the rule is shown in the highlighted section of the below image.

NOTE: All 4 of the above pointers should be checked and configured accordingly.

  • If you are using a custom RCM Field to pass the Event Reason from RCM to Onboarding:

    #1
    Check the Suite Integration to validate if the data is passed from RCM to Onboarding:

    Prerequisite: The permission needed for the user who is accessing this page is "Employee Central HRIS OData API (read-only)"

    1. Log in to the instance
    2. Click on New Tab "+" (open new tab in the same browser).
    3. Take the application URL and paste it followed by /xi/ui/apitest/pages/getEligibleRecordsTest.xhtml (E.g, https://pmsalesdemo8.successfactors.com/xi/ui/apitest/pages/getEligibleRecordsTest.xhtml)

entry.title: SAP in the Leaders category at the 2025 IDC MarketScape for utility meter data management systems
entry.content:
Please find below the SAP evaluation from IDC MarketScape: Worldwide Utility Meter Data Management Systems 2025 Vendor Assessment:

SAP serves clients across more than 180 countries with over 105,000 employees worldwide. Its utilities division delivers digital solutions to hundreds of live MDMS customers, encompassing electricity, gas, water, and heat sectors, with implementations from small municipal networks to multi-million endpoint portfolios. SAP S/4HANA Utilities integrates core utility functions‚Äîincluding energy data management, device management, billing, and customer engagement‚Äîinto a unified software suite designed for deployment at scale and with multi-commodity, multi-tenant support.

The Energy Data Management and Device Management modules within SAP S/4HANA Utilities provide end-to-end capabilities for collecting, validating, storing, and managing both interval and discrete meter data. These modules support two-way communication with a diverse range of smart meters and head-end systems, enabling asynchronous automated meter readings, remote connect/disconnect, firmware management, and real-time event handling. Advanced VEE functions ensure near real-time data quality, compliance, and readiness for billing, settlement, or analytics, with customizable rules for anomaly detection and automated exception handling. SAP‚Äôs high-volume architecture scales to billions of meter readings, using batch and parallel processing, robust audit and version controls, and granular role-based security to deliver performance and reliability for large utility deployments.

Distinctive capabilities include vendor-agnostic device modelling, multi-commodity management under a single system, flexible integration for third-party AMI and IoT devices, and support for complex business requirements such as TOU tariffs, prepayment, and regulatory reporting. SAP S/4HANA Utilities features embedded analytics and operational dashboards‚Äîpowered by SAP Fiori and Analytics Cloud‚Äîsupporting consumption and asset analysis, anomaly prediction, KPI monitoring, and demand forecasting. The system integrates directly with billing, contract management, and financial processes, facilitating seamless meter-to-cash and regulatory compliance workflows. Utilities can visualize customer insights, consumption patterns, and field operations through interactive dashboards and mobile/web portals.

SAP delivers S/4HANA Utilities via multiple deployment models including on-premises, hybrid, private cloud, and‚Äîplanned for wider rollout‚Äîpublic cloud SaaS. Currently, 80% of live deployments are on-premises, with increasing momentum toward private and hybrid cloud configurations and emerging public cloud solutions. Commercial packaging is modular, with options for perpetual licenses, subscription models based on meter points managed, and outcome-based options. Trial periods are standard and SAP Value Engineering tools support ROI justification for technology investments and transformation initiatives.

Services and support are structured in tiered offerings‚Äîfrom basic to premium and mission-critical levels‚Äîproviding live chat, virtual assistant, 24/7 expert access, and proactive lifecycle management. Dedicated customer success managers and solution architects guide project implementation, process optimization, and regulatory alignment. Knowledge bases, online communities, and training hubs complement peer engagement and feedback via customer councils, shaping feature development and

product strategy. SAP‚Äôs support coverage spans over 10 languages, with compliance maintained through regular software updates and professional services across more than 140 jurisdictions.

The partner ecosystem for S/4HANA Utilities spans global SIs (e.g., Accenture, Capgemini, Deloitte, Wipro), smart grid OEMs and solution providers (e.g., Itron, Landis+Gyr, Sensus), utility-software and analytics providers (e.g., SEW, NET2GRID, C3 AI, Bidgely) and cloud infrastructure vendors (e.g., AWS, Microsoft, Google Cloud). Integration is facilitated through SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), with open APIs supporting extensibility, data sharing, and fast onboarding of specialized partner solutions for outage management, DER integration, demand response, and network optimization.

Innovation at SAP is organized around AI enablement, cloud-native architectures, and process automation. Recent enhancements include AI-driven Joule for anomaly detection, consumption forecasting, automated validation, and predictive asset maintenance. The roadmap prioritizes generative AI for agentic workflows, natural language processing for customer engagement, and large language model integration via BTP. The system‚Äôs flexibility supports distributed intelligence at the edge through partner extensions and SAP IoT capabilities, positioning utilities to manage digitalization, energy transition, regulatory change, and new market requirements efficiently and securely.

Strengths

  • SAP has a presence in utilities in every continent and almost every country, delivering digital solutions to hundreds of live MDMS customers. This makes the extent and diversity of its customer base in terms of subindustries, client size, and geographic footprint vast and referenceability high.
  • From a features and functionalities perspective, SAP‚Äôs Energy Data Management and Device Management modules support smart and interval meters as well as advanced metering infrastructure with a comprehensive range of capabilities covering large commercial and industrial clients, including Field Service & Work Order Integration, Time-of-Day and Prepayment Operations, Consumer Engagement & Energy Management and Predictive modelling.
  • SAP solutions are integrated by design, sharing a common technology platform, a consistent look and feel, and a customer-friendly user experience and UI, thanks also to SAP Fiori.

Challenges

  • Customers indicate that one area for improvement with SAP is customer service, with some users reporting challenges in receiving timely and effective support for their needs. Feedback suggests that customer service experiences can vary, and addressing support responsiveness could enhance overall customer satisfaction with SAP‚Äôs offerings.
  • When it comes to pricing models, SAP‚Äôs offering is currently limited to ‚Äúsubscription based on meter points managed‚Äù for its SaaS deployments. It does not provide alternatives such as user/seat licensing or consumption-based pricing, which constrains flexibility for customers with varying usage patterns or organizational structures.

entry.title: Re: Accessing SAP Cloud Platform via AWS Direct Connect
entry.content:
Hello there gurus! I hope one of you can help me get a very clear answer here. I'm pretty sure this will help many other people trying to get to the same point here.

Can on-premises systems connected to AWS privately via AWS Direct Connect links and utilizing Transit Gateway (TGW) for routing, reach the BTP Integration Suite (Cloud Foundry) HTTPS endpoints mentioned above exclusively over the private AWS Direct Connect path, without any traffic traversing the public internet? Note that the OnPrem system is the one initiating the call to the BTP Integration Suite (Cloud Foundry) HTTPS endpoints.

Being a bit more technical, does SAP advertise the public IP address ranges for the HTTPS API endpoints of BTP Integration Suite (Cloud Foundry) via BGP over an AWS Direct Connect Public VIF? If the answer is "Yes," does the network traffic originating from an on-premise network, passing through an AWS Direct Connect Public VIF and an AWS Transit Gateway to these SAP SaaS BTP Integration Suite (Cloud Foundry) HTTPS endpoints, remain entirely on the AWS global network backbone without traversing the public internet at any point?

To be completely unambiguous, please consider this scenario: A customer has an on-premise data centre connected to an AWS VPC via Direct Connect and a Transit Gateway. This AWS environment has no Internet Gateway (IGW), no NAT Gateway, and no other path to the public internet, creating a completely isolated private network. In this specific scenario, can a system in the on-premise data center successfully establish a connection to the HTTPS API endpoint of an SAP SaaS application like BTP Integration Suite (Cloud Foundry)?

entry.title: Re: Packaging specification determination for pick-HUs in...
entry.content:
Good day @vicentejarque 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at these references, they provide more detailed guidance:

Packaging Specification, Pack Handling Units - Advanced

To summarise, when you use the ‚ÄúPack Handling Unit ‚Äì Advanced‚Äù option, be aware that the system can only automatically determine packaging specification if conditions like, existence of a packaging specification for the designated material, the relevant profile is active, and the process is triggered from the delivery or warehouse task creation. In this case, the packaging material is proposed from the packaging specification defined through the delivered master data setup.

Your understanding is correct in regard to RF picking. In public cloud, it is currently not possible to determine packaging specifications automatically for Pick-Hus created during RF picking.

I recommend adhering to a clean-core (best practice) approach if you want consistend packaging behaviour for picking and staging, which requires you to use the Handling Unit ‚Äì Advanced app to pre-pack or predefine HUs at the delivery stage, then RF picking will consume them automatically.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: ABAP2XLSX and XLSM
entry.content:
Hello there. 

Is it possible to work with ABAP2XLSX and XLSM (macro-enabled) files?

I‚Äôm trying to migrate some legacy developments that currently use OLE2 objects to ABAP2XLSX, but I‚Äôm running into issues.

We have a solution where a macro-enabled Excel template (stored on the application server) is downloaded by the program, filled in with case data, and then sent to a supplier to complete.
The template contains several VBA-based validations ‚Äî for example, a cell must be filled if certain other cells are completed, verifying that an entered EAN code is valid, and so on.

I‚Äôm trying to achieve the same behavior using ABAP2XLSX, but I‚Äôm getting errors when opening the generated file.

I‚Äôve created a simplified example of what I‚Äôm trying to do ‚Äî Excel file includes a small macro, and with the ABAP code I‚Äôm attempting to fill it in and then download it again.
(For the Excel validations to work, you first need to fill in cell B2.)

Do you know if this is possible with ABAP2XLSX?

REPORT ztest.

PARAMETERS:
  pa_banfn TYPE banfn OBLIGATORY.

START-OF-SELECTION.

  DATA:
    lv_rc            TYPE i,
    lv_filename      TYPE char1024,
    lv_filename_down TYPE string,
    lt_filetable     TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF file_table.

  SELECT eban~matnr, maktx
   INTO TABLE @DATA(lt_eban)
   FROM eban
   INNER JOIN makt
    ON eban~matnr EQ makt~matnr
     AND makt~spras EQ @SY-langu
   WHERE banfn EQ @PA_banfn
     AND loekz EQ @Space.
  IF sy-subrc NE 0.
    MESSAGE 'Expedient doesnt exists' TYPE 'S' DISPLAY LIKE 'E'.
    RETURN.
  ENDIF.

  CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>file_open_dialog
    EXPORTING
*     window_title            = lv_titulo
      file_filter             = '(*.xlsm)|*.xlsm|'
      initial_directory       = 'U:\'
    CHANGING
      file_table              = lt_filetable
      rc                      = lv_rc
    EXCEPTIONS
      file_open_dialog_failed = 1
      cntl_error              = 2
      error_no_gui            = 3
      not_supported_by_gui    = 4
      OTHERS                  = 5.
  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    RETURN.
  ENDIF.

  READ TABLE lt_filetable
  INTO lv_filename
  INDEX 1.
  IF sy-subrc NE 0.
    RETURN.
  ENDIF.

  CALL FUNCTION 'SO_SPLIT_FILE_AND_PATH'
    EXPORTING
      full_name = lv_filename
    IMPORTING
*     STRIPPED_NAME       =
      file_path = lv_filename_down
    EXCEPTIONS
      x_error   = 1
      OTHERS    = 2.
  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    RETURN.
  ENDIF.
  CONCATENATE lv_filename_down sy-datum sy-uzeit '.xlsm' INTO lv_filename_down.

  DATA(lo_reader)    = CAST zif_excel_reader( NEW zcl_excel_reader_2007( ) ).
  DATA(lo_excel)     = lo_reader->load_file( lv_filename ).
  DATA(lo_worksheet) = lo_excel->get_worksheet_by_index( 1 ).

  TRY.
      CALL METHOD lo_worksheet->set_table
        EXPORTING
          ip_table           = lt_eban
*         ip_hdr_style       =
*         ip_body_style      =
          ip_table_title     = space
          ip_top_left_column = 'A'
          ip_top_left_row    = 5
*         ip_transpose       =
          ip_no_header       = abap_true.
    CATCH zcx_excel .
      RETURN.
  ENDTRY.

  lo_worksheet->set_cell( ip_row    = 1
                          ip_column = 'B'
                          ip_value  =  pa_banfn ).

*--------------------------------------------------------------------*
* Save file
*--------------------------------------------------------------------*

  DATA:
    lv_xdata     TYPE xstring,
    lt_rawdata   TYPE solix_tab,
    lv_bytecount TYPE i,
    cl_writer    TYPE REF TO zif_excel_writer.

  CREATE OBJECT cl_writer TYPE zcl_excel_writer_2007.
  lv_xdata = cl_writer->write_file( lo_excel ).
  lt_rawdata = cl_bcs_convert=>xstring_to_solix( iv_xstring  = lv_xdata ).
  lv_bytecount = xstrlen( lv_xdata ).

  CALL METHOD cl_gui_frontend_services=>gui_download
    EXPORTING
      bin_filesize            = lv_bytecount
      filename                = lv_filename_down
      filetype                = 'BIN'
    CHANGING
      data_tab                = lt_rawdata
    EXCEPTIONS
      file_write_error        = 1
      no_batch                = 2
      gui_refuse_filetransfer = 3
      invalid_type            = 4
      no_authority            = 5
      unknown_error           = 6
      header_not_allowed      = 7
      separator_not_allowed   = 8
      filesize_not_allowed    = 9
      header_too_long         = 10
      dp_error_create         = 11
      dp_error_send           = 12
      dp_error_write          = 13
      unknown_dp_error        = 14
      access_denied           = 15
      dp_out_of_memory        = 16
      disk_full               = 17
      dp_timeout              = 18
      file_not_found          = 19
      dataprovider_exception  = 20
      control_flush_error     = 21
      not_supported_by_gui    = 22
      error_no_gui            = 23
      OTHERS                  = 24.
  IF sy-subrc <> 0.
    MESSAGE ID sy-msgid TYPE 'S' NUMBER sy-msgno
               WITH sy-msgv1 sy-msgv2 sy-msgv3 sy-msgv4
               DISPLAY LIKE 'E'.
  ELSE.
    MESSAGE 'Done' TYPE 'S'.
  ENDIF.

 

The excel file has this content:

And a macro with this code:

Private Sub Workbook_BeforeSave(ByVal SaveAsUI As Boolean, Cancel As Boolean)
    Dim ws As Worksheet
    Dim lastRow As Long
    Dim i As Long
    Dim ean As String
    Dim msg As String
    Dim invalid As Boolean
    
    Set ws = ThisWorkbook.Sheets("Prices")
    
    nif = Trim(ws.Range("B2").Value)
    If nif = "" Then Exit Sub
    
    lastRow = ws.Cells(ws.Rows.Count, "A").End(xlUp).Row
    
    invalid = False
    msg = ""
    
    ' Recorre desde la fila 5 en adelante
    For i = 5 To lastRow
        Dim mat As String, price As Variant
        
        mat = Trim(ws.Cells(i, "A").Value)
        price = ws.Cells(i, "C").Value
        ean = Trim(ws.Cells(i, "D").Value)
        
        ' Si hay material, el precio debe estar informado
        If mat <> "" And (price = "" Or Not IsNumeric(price)) Then
            msg = msg & vbCrLf & "Fila " & i & ": Falta precio para el material """ & mat & """"
            invalid = True
        End If
        
        ' Si hay EAN, validar formato y d√≠gito de control
        If ean <> "" Then
            If Not IsValidEAN(ean) Then
                msg = msg & vbCrLf & "Fila " & i & ": C√≥digo EAN """ & ean & """ no v√°lido"
                invalid = True
            End If
        End If
    Next i
    
    If invalid Then
        MsgBox "Se encontraron errores:" & vbCrLf & msg, vbExclamation, "Validaci√≥n de datos"
        Cancel = True ' Evita guardar si hay errores
    Else
        MsgBox "Validaci√≥n correcta. Guardando archivo...", vbInformation, "Validaci√≥n de datos"
    End If
End Sub

Private Function IsValidEAN(ean As String) As Boolean
    Dim sum As Long, checkDigit As Integer, i As Integer
    Dim digits() As String
    
    ean = Replace(ean, " ", "")
    If Not ean Like String(Len(ean), "#") Then
        IsValidEAN = False
        Exit Function
    End If
    
    Select Case Len(ean)
        Case 8, 13
            ReDim digits(1 To Len(ean))
            For i = 1 To Len(ean)
                digits(i) = Mid(ean, i, 1)
            Next i
            
            sum = 0
            For i = Len(ean) - 1 To 1 Step -1
                If (Len(ean) - i) Mod 2 = IIf(Len(ean) = 13, 0, 1) Then
                    sum = sum + digits(i) * 3
                Else
                    sum = sum + digits(i)
                End If
            Next i
            checkDigit = (10 - (sum Mod 10)) Mod 10
            IsValidEAN = (checkDigit = digits(Len(ean)))
        Case Else
            IsValidEAN = False
    End Select
End Function

Thanks in advance

entry.title: Re: Link between SAP B1 Picklist and its target document...
entry.content:
Hi @anandrd ,

The link lies in the picklist details table (PKL1) and its related document details table, which could be DLN1, INV1, etc.

With Delivery Note as example:

(Object) - PKL1.BaseObject links to DLN1.BaseType
(Entry ID) - PKL1.OrderEntry links to DLN1.BaseEntry and also PKL1.AbsEntry to DLN1.PickIdNo
(Line) - PKL1.OrderLine links to DLN1.BaseLine

I hope it helps.

BR,
Felipe

                "sourcePath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap.odm:2.0:User']['purchasingGroup']",
                "preserveArrayWithSingleElement": true,
                "optional": true,
                "targetPath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap.odm:2.0:User']['purchasingGroup']"
            }
        ]
    },
    "group": {
        "mappings": [
            {
                "sourcePath": "$.id",
                "targetVariable": "entityIdSourceSystem"
            },
            {
                "sourcePath": "$['urn:sap:cloud:scim:schemas:extension:custom:2.0:Group']['name']",
                "targetPath": "$['urn:sap:cloud:scim:schemas:extension:custom:2.0:Group']['name']"
            },
            {
                "sourcePath": "$.displayName",
                "targetPath": "$.displayName"
            },
            {
                "sourcePath": "$.members",
                "preserveArrayWithSingleElement": true,
                "optional": true,
                "targetPath": "$.members"
            },
            {
                "sourcePath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:Group']['type']",
                "optional": true,
                "targetPath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:Group']['type']"
            },
            {
                "sourcePath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:Group']['supportedOperations']",
                "optional": true,
                "targetPath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:Group']['supportedOperations']"
            },
            {
                "sourcePath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:Group']['externalName']",
                "optional": true,
                "targetPath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:Group']['externalName']"
            },
            {
                "condition": "'%ips.application.id%' !== 'null'",
                "constant": "%ips.application.id%",
                "targetPath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:Group']['applicationId']"
            }
        ]
    }
}

The groups in IAS are correctly assigned to the corresponding application  ID (SAC).
However, when provisioning from Local Identity Directory ‚Üí SAC, only other groups are provisioned successfully ‚Äî the groups that have the Application ID (SAC) assigned are not provisioned at all.

Why are the groups with the assigned applicationId being skipped?
Do I need an additional condition, property, or filter in IPS to make sure these groups are included in the provisioning?

One more question: when the groups are provisioned from the Corporate Identity Provider, the Application ID in the groups in IAS gets removed. How can this be fixed?

Thanks in advance for your help
Best regards

entry.title: Re: I am getting a blank page when I preview my RAP servi...
entry.content:
Hello,

I had the same issue when trying to use the preview functionality in a Service Binding. There is a workaround that worked for me: Create a Communication Scenario, then add the inbound service to the Communication Scenario and publish it locally. Take a look at this tutorial (Steps 9-11).
Expose a Standard Core Data Service for ABAP Environment 

Best regards,

Patrik Balazs
